Asia continues to grow and you know I

what was left then were a series of

producing the kind of economic growth

didn't know what spark was it was going

one way to characterize it is you've got

but our simple organizing principles
that allow people to you know recruit

what you see are a lot of regional

you know the big countries wanted to

and that's a broader contest as well and
and those things I think are merging
our goal should be to help usher in a

it's a really bad neighborhood and they

suddenly you've got these protests in

himself into Crimea and now what you've

around him
fierce Russian nationalists suddenly

he now finds himself in a place where

possible ideas should be pacient
but you know one of the things that I

Yara Chiron once said there were things

see from there when I became prime
minister yeah what's the biggest
takeaway for you well I there are a
couple of things I think that what we've

you had a continent that 20 years ago
was perceived as falling off a cliff
that now has six of the 10
fastest-growing economies because of the

the Bush administration Clinton
administration have done along with our
international partners and and the
countries themselves they have
drastically cut hiv/aids drastically cut

a growing middle class when you travel

are seeing is that we are as well

investments primarily because they want
to get natural resources out of Africa
we are positioned better than anybody to
really partner with a young vibrant
continent that has huge geopolitical

Asia
a lot of people have questioned well
what does this really mean concretely is
this just for show but the truth of

and now our alliances with traditional
allies like Japan Korea the Philippines
Thailand molasses have never been
stronger we have a deeper relationship
with the ASEAN countries in Southeast

they are wanting us to be in there much
more heavily than than before and as a

strategic possibilities there that
didn't exist same is true in Latin

America that's all been pushed aside and
it's now countries like Chile and Peru
and even a country like Colombia that
had so many problems that is now on the

so I guess the point is that we've been
looking at opportunities even as we're
trying to manage problems I have learned
however that and this is just a lesson
that I think American presidents have to
learn over and over and over again is
that when we intervene militarily there
are unintended consequences sometimes
it's necessary for us to do it but we
have to think those consequences through
I'll give you an example of a lesson I
had to learn that still has you know
ramifications to this day and that is
our participation in the coalition that
overthrew Gaddafi in Libya I absolutely
believe that it was the right thing to
do when people say look at the chaos
shoulda let Qaddafi's stay there they
forget that the Arab Spring had come

be Syria
right because Gaddafi was not gonna be

more disruption more destruction but
what is also true is is that I think we

underestimated the need to come in full

it's the day after Gaddafi's gone when
everybody's feeling good and everybody's
